data.text: Is Cycling a Good Cardio Exercise?
Hello everyone one , i have a question , can cycling replace running ? Is cycling sufficient as a cardio exercice ? Since i can't run due to some problems . Thank you so much .
Yes, you just have to cycle at least 5 times as many miles
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: ummmm maybe two and a half??
data.author: Fintan Culwin

data.text: yes but you get to coast down the hills!!
data.author: Andrew G Johnston

data.text: , I can cycle 200miles in a day, I can't run more than 10, so maybe 20 times as many miles üòÇüòÇü§£
data.author: Alan Tucker

data.text: Cycling is great for cardio. Try riding in the mountains on a fully loaded tourer... However cycling works different muscles than running + cycling doesn't produce same load on your skeletal system. If you're serious runner, cycling won't replace it but it would supplement it very well.
data.author: W√ºlf Gl√´b

data.text: Of course. Runners are people without bikes üòÖ
data.author: Ania Proczek

data.text: Yes, very good for cardio. I know a few aging runners who have taken up cycling as it is not so stressful on the leg joints
data.author: Ian Hallett

data.text: Cycling can be your replacement but do noy engage as many muscles as running. Picture a cyclist with a big belly, i am sure you have seen one
data.author: Damian Terpitz

data.text: The only thing cycling won‚Äôt be able to replicate is the impact, which is probably the very reason you‚Äôre wanting to get away from running. There is some research out there showing the impact from running helps with bone density. I think if you make sure to include weight lifting and brisk walking, you should be ok.
data.author: Melanie Thompson

data.text: You can achieve the same cardio results with cycling that you can running. You can also achieve them swimming or just jumping up and down. Cardio is about the heart and lungs. If you were working with cardio goals and know your correct heart rate and co2 max you can calculate your zones and then work with them to achieve your cardio goals. Do not use those charts you see on gym walls. They are very inaccurate. Have a stress test performed so you can begin with the correct numbers.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: Join a cycling club üëçüèª
data.author: Alessandro Monty

data.text:
www.cyclinguk.org are brill
Cycling UK | The UK‚Äôs cycling charity
cyclinguk.org
data.author: Andrew G Johnston

data.text: Wheels make the world go round. Cycling can replace all movement.
data.author: Laurence Hendrick

data.text: Of course. Much better than running in just about as many ways as possible.
data.author: Michael Manning

data.text: You can just cycle harder and faster if you want to duplicate the high-intensity cardio of running, but be careful to stay in the correct gears and don't overdo it on the leg muscles. I'm a lifelong cyclist, but I love to get out on my inline skates as often as possible. I find that workout has it all: works my core much more than cycling, lower impact than running and loads of fun!
data.author: Greg Robinson

data.text: Absolutely! I have two dodgy knees and tore my calf muscle 10 years back. When running I always have issues after a certain distance but never have an issue with cycling - ever!
data.author: Andrew G Johnston

data.text: Back in the 80s, when doing some poorly designed PT with the marine instructors at the Coronado Amphibious Base, they caused both of my knees to get severely stress fractured, to the point where I couldn't continue to do the daily six-mile runs. They, instead, had me doing a daily PT routine in the gym, which included a full run on the Life-Cycle. After doing the Life Cycle daily, I was able to ramp up the resistance to an incredible amount during the hill-climbing program. The end result was that at the end of four months, I got back to being able to run again. When I did my final run for the graduation test, I had knocked six minutes off of my original six-mile run time. So the answer is yes.
data.author: Bob Breeze

data.text: To me, cycling is the best exercise. I can't run long distance because of a back problem. But with cycling I can stay in shape and lose weight much more effectively than other types of exercise. I put on a lot of weight during the months where I am not tour cycling, even if I exercise every day. But as soon as I start with my 100 kilometers a day, then I slim down within 2 weeks. No matter how much I eat and drink.
data.author: Claus Andersen

data.text: agree. The best remedy against depression. And you can eat almost whatever, almost.
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: Cycling is great if you can't run as it's zero impact on the body. Like running, you can make it as easy or as hard as you want it to be.
data.author: Daz Speck

data.text: I got a chronic leg injury from running about 32y ago but I was already cycling. I quit running and since have cycled and walked. Am 72. Cycled a very hilly 55m ride on rough roads on Sunday.
data.author: Gear√≥id √ì Laoi

data.text: I would say yes. Add some swimming for a full body workout
data.author: Paul Rollason

data.text: No doubt that cycling is a good alternative to rung.
data.author: Peter Sroka

data.text: It did for myself
data.author: Pete Lushington

data.text: You get the cardio‚Ä¶. Without the impact to your joints‚Ä¶.. It‚Äôs a big deal to we who are older‚Ä¶

data.text: For sure...but it won't help ur run in my experience
data.author: Ron Powers

data.text: Yes, cycling can give you the cardio. But it doesn't give the weight bearing exercise that is needed for keeping bone density, so you may want to make sure you are also doing plenty of walking, or appropriate gym work. :-)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: I recently have been curious about this statement. Road biking on a smooth surface, I agree with it. Mountain biking or similar , I am not sure if I agree.
data.author: Mark Hardies

data.text: , I am not positive on that point either.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Swimming and stair climbing are also great for cardio
data.author: Karen Connor

data.text: Rowing, weight training specific to cycling, swimming, spin class is excellent for pure aerobic. There are many alternatives to running
data.author: David Atwell

data.text: Practice cadence. You shouldn‚Äôt have to force the pedals down.
data.author: Tim Attwood

data.text: Of course it can.
data.author: Andrea Collisson

data.text: That‚Äôs the way it goes for many runners. Knack your knees, then switch to cycling.
data.author: Nigel White

data.text: Absolutely. Running is hard on the body, especially knees. Cycling is a solid alternative, but we all must adjust as our bodies show wear and tear. I have run many marathons but my time for running is up. Biking is wonderful. You can enjoy a slow ride or do endurance or do fast biking. It‚Äôs all there. Be safe, however.
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: I agree. However, our bodies need weight-bearing exercise, such as walking and weight lifting, which cycling does not provide.
data.author: James William Langford

data.text: yes.
data.author: Ingo Tophoven

data.text: Try kickbiking if you want something that stresses the lower body and hips more than bicycling. But sure, you can bike instead of run. And kickbiking will translate better to running than bicycling will in terms of kinetic patterns, and will strengthen your lower limbs in a more complementary way to running than cycling.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: In terms of cardio only, which is your question, cycling will do it.
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text: Inform yourself better about cardio...and not from the gym ;)
data.author: Olimid CƒÉmƒÉru≈£

data.text: The only thing better is swimming.
data.author: John Ames

data.text: Any activity that raises your heart rate is cardio. I really wish watching TV and eating junk food would rise the heart rate. If so, we will not have obese people.
data.author: Marius Brumaru
